headline.main: Fighting the War in Your Head

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students will analyze the experiences of a fictional soldier in a war and create a mental health profile for that individual. They then emulate psychiatrists and propose treatment strategies for their particular soldier's post-traumatic stress disorder.

byline.original: By PRISCILLA CHAN and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: New findings that aspirin may prevent colon cancer have bolstered a growing area of research into whether humble aspirin or drugs like it will work against a range of malignancies. It will be years before the question is answered. Until then, experts say, people should be wary of taking the drugs on speculation, because they all can have side effects. But the intriguing new colon cancer findings -- and a wide array of test tube, animal and epidemiological data -- are encouraging scientists working in the field.

headline.main: Aspirin, and Cousins, Take a New Role in the War on Cancer

docs.abstract: Findings that aspirin may prevent colon cancer bolster growing area of research into whether aspirin and similar anti-inflammatory drugs will work against range of malignancies; more than dozen studies are under way, involving patients at high risk of cancer of lung, breast, skin, prostate, colon, mouth, bladder or esophagus; experts say people should be wary of taking drugs until firm answer is in because they all can have side effects; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At age 40 Jonathan Shay had life by the tail. He had his own lab at Massachusetts General Hospital and several papers published in prestigious journals. He was focused on the biochemistry of brain-cell death, with its relevance to strokes. But life takes sudden twists. As Sophocles wrote in Athens 2,400 years ago, no one should be counted happy who is still alive. Dr. Shay soon had reasons to contemplate that line, and plenty of time.

headline.main: Exploring Combat and the Psyche, Beginning With Homer

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Jonathan Shay, psychiatrist who specializes in treating psychological damage combat inflicts on soldiers; he says his approach is woven out of different strands of his life: part neuroscience, party evolutionary theory, part psychiatric empathy and part Homer; two of his books are Achilles in Vietnam, which compares experiences of soldiers in Trojan and Vietnam Wars, and Odysseus in America, which is about spiritual and psychic pitfalls that await combat veterans returning to civilian life; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What's at stake in a name? When it comes to prescription drugs, sometimes your physical or mental health. Just ask my patient Lisa. For nearly half of her 40 years, Lisa struggled with bipolar disorder and had finally been stabilized on a number of medications, including the mood-stabilizing anticonvulsant Lamictal. Two weeks after a routine office visit, she called complaining of irritability and insomnia, early warning signs of a relapse.

headline.main: Do Spelling and Penmanship Count? In Medicine, You Bet

docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman article on potentially lethal prescription errors that are made because certain drugs either sound alike or have similar spelling; says problem that is aggravated by fact that many prescriptions are phoned in to pharmacist or written in a doctor's notoriously bad handwriting (M)
